title: Evaluation of Reader Training Processes by Comparing Clinical Interpretations to Centralized Expert Reads
description_brief: This study is designed to evaluate the agreement between florbetapir F 18 scan interpretation in the clinic and by expert readers.

groups.title: Clinical Practice Scans
groups.description:
241 florbetapir F 18 scans and final scan reports interpreted in a clinical setting were collected from physicians across the country. These results were then compared to expert panel interpretations for the same scans.

florbetapir F 18: No study drug was administered in this study - scans previously acquired in the course of clinical practice.

groups.title: Clinical Practice Scans
groups.description:

measures.title: Age, Customized
measures.description: Age was not collected in this study.

measures.title: Sex/Gender, Customized
measures.description: Gender was not collected in this study.

measures.title: Region of Enrollment
measures.description: All scans were collected from imaging centers in the US.

outcomeMeasures.title: Agreement Between Expert Panel and Clinical Practice Reads
outcomeMeasures.description: Agreement between expert panel consensus scan interpretations and clinical practice reader scan interpretations was calculated as a weighted Kappa value across all cases and all clinical practice readers.

eventGroups.title: Clinical Practice Scans
eventGroups.description:
241 florbetapir F 18 scans and final scan reports interpreted in a clinical setting were collected from physicians across the country. These results were then compared to expert panel interpretations for the same scans.

florbetapir F 18: No study drug was administered in this study - scans previously acquired in the course of clinical practice.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial evaluates agreement between florbetapir F 18 scan interpretation in the clinic and by expert readers — this describes a diagnostic imaging/read interpretation study (amyloid PET), not a therapeutic intervention. citeturn0search2

Act: The imaging agent is florbetapir F 18, marketed as Amyvid, a PET radiopharmaceutical that binds beta-amyloid neuritic plaques and is FDA‑approved for estimating brain amyloid plaque density in adults being evaluated for cognitive impairment. This is a diagnostic tracer (molecular imaging) rather than a drug intended to modify disease or improve cognition. citeturn0search2turn0search1

Act — supporting evidence from the literature: Florbetapir F 18 selectively binds Aβ plaques in brain tissue and correlates with postmortem measures of Aβ, supporting its use as an amyloid PET ligand for identifying Alzheimer pathology. The tracer’s intended use and limitations (adjunct to other evaluations; not for monitoring therapy or predicting dementia) are described in regulatory and sponsor materials. citeturn0search4turn0search3

Reflect: Given the trial focus (reader training/interpretation agreement) and that florbetapir F 18 is a diagnostic PET agent (not a biologic or small‑molecule therapeutic, nor a cognitive enhancer or neuropsychiatric treatment), the correct category is 'N/A' (diagnostic/other non‑therapeutic). This classification aligns with the agent’s indication and the study objective. citeturn0search2turn0search8

Web search results (sources used): - FDA/sponsor approval and product information for Amyvid (florbetapir F 18) describing indication as PET imaging for beta‑amyloid in cognitive impairment. citeturn0search2 - PubMed article validating florbetapir F‑18 as a histopathologically validated beta‑amyloid PET imaging agent. citeturn0search1 - Development/clinical trial summaries showing florbetapir distinguishes AD from controls and correlates with postmortem Aβ. citeturn0search3 - Correlation studies showing florbetapir binding corresponds to amyloid plaque measures in postmortem tissue. citeturn0search4 - Amyvid patient/sponsor information page summarizing use and reader training recommendations. citeturn0search8
